questions.prompt: When did Henry VIII die?
questions.explanation: Henry VIII died on the 28th of January 1547.

questions.prompt: Which of the following lines from Shakespeare’s plays and poems is often still quoted?
options: I have nothing to offer but blood, toil, tears and sweat
questions.explanation: ‘The darling buds of May’ is a line from William Shakespeare’s play Sonnet 18 – Shall I Compare Thee To A Summer’s Day.

questions.prompt: Which TWO of the following are fundamental principles of British life?
options: Tolerance of those with different faiths and beliefs
questions.explanation: Tolerance of those with different faiths and beliefs and the rule of law are fundamental principles of British life.

questions.prompt: What is the capital city of the UK?
questions.explanation: The capital city of the UK is London.

questions.prompt: Which of the following statements about Mary, Queen of Scotland, is NOT true?
options: She spent most of her childhood in France
She gave her throne to her Protestant son, James VI of Scotland.
She was kept her prisoner for 20 years
questions.explanation: The queen of Scotland, Mary Stuart (often now called ‘Mary, Queen of Scots’) was a Catholic.

questions.prompt: When did Ireland become unified with England, Wales and Scotland?
questions.explanation: In 1801, Ireland became unified with England, Scotland and Wales after the Act of Union of 1800. This created the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland.

questions.prompt: What is Hogmanay?
options: The equivalent of Christmas Day in Scotland
The equivalent of New Year’s Eve in Scotland
The equivalent of Christmas Day in Wales
The equivalent of New Year’s Eve in Wales
questions.explanation: In Scotland, the 31st of December is called Hogmanay.

questions.prompt: The devolved administrations of Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland each have their own civil service:
questions.explanation: The devolved administrations each have their own civil service.

questions.prompt: On Remembrance Day, there is a two-minute silence at 11 AM to commemorate those who died fighting during the First World War.
questions.explanation: On Remembrance Day at 11.00 am there is a two-minute silence and wreaths are laid at the Cenotaph in Whitehall, London.

questions.prompt: What is the distance between the north coast of Scotland and the south-west corner of England?
questions.explanation: In the UK, the longest distance on the mainland is from John O’Groats on the north coast of Scotland to Land’s End in the south-west corner of England. It is about 870 miles (approximately 1,400 kilometres).

questions.prompt: Who was Henry Purcell?
questions.explanation: Henry Purcell (1659-95) was the organist at Westminster Abbey. He wrote church music, operas and other pieces, and developed a British style distinct from that elsewhere in Europe.

questions.prompt: How are life peers appointed?
options: By the monarch on the advice of the Prime Minister
By the Prime Minister on the advice of the Queen
questions.explanation: Life peers are appointed by the monarch on the advice of the Prime Minister.

questions.prompt: Where is the Giant’s Causeway located?
questions.explanation: The Giant’s Causeway is located on the north-east coast of Northern Ireland.

questions.prompt: Who proposed that enemy aircrafts could be detected by radio waves and is responsible for the development of the radar?
questions.explanation: The radar was developed by Scotsman Sir Robert Watson-Watt (1892-1973), who proposed that enemy aircraft could be detected by radio waves. The first successful radar test took place in 1935.

questions.prompt: During Halloween people carve lanterns out of ______ and put a candle inside of them.
questions.explanation: During Halloween people carve lanterns out of pumpkins and put a candle inside of them.

questions.prompt: In England, Wales and Northern Ireland, if an accused person is aged 18, the case will be heard in a Youth Court:
questions.explanation: In England, Wales and Northern Ireland, if an accused person is aged 10 to 17, the case is normally heard in a Youth Court in front of up to three specially trained magistrates or a District Judge.

questions.prompt: The Prime Minister appoints about 40 senior MPs to become ministers in charge of departments.
questions.explanation: The Prime Minister appoints about 20 senior MPs to become ministers in charge of departments.

questions.prompt: Royal Ascot is a four-day horse race meeting in Berkshire attended by members of the Royal Family:
questions.explanation: Royal Ascot , a five-day race meeting in Berkshire attended by members of the Royal Family.

questions.prompt: Who sat at the House of Lords during the Middle Ages?
options: Knights, who were usually smaller landowners
Wealthy people from towns and cities
questions.explanation: During the Middle Ages, great landowners and bishops sat in the House of Lords.

questions.prompt: Which of the following statements regarding Scottish television is TRUE?
options: There is a channel with programmes in the Gaelic language
There are three channels in the Gaelic language
All programmes are broadcasted in English
There are no specific programmes to Scotland
questions.explanation: In Scotland, some Scotland-specific programmes are shown and there is also a channel with programmes in the Gaelic language.

questions.prompt: Where does the biggest and most well-known Fringe Festival take place?
questions.explanation: The biggest and most well-known Fringe Festival is the Edinburgh Festival Fringe.

questions.prompt: The UN was set up after the First World War and aims to prevent war and promote international peace and security:
questions.explanation: The UN was set up after the Second World War and aims to prevent war and promote international peace and security.

questions.prompt: Which of the following countries was NOT part of the Central Powers during the First World War?
questions.explanation: During the First World War Serbia formed part of the Allied powers.

questions.prompt: What is played at important national occasions and at events attended by the King or the Royal Family?
questions.explanation: The National Anthem of the UK is ‘God Save the King’ is played at important national occasions and at events attended by the King or the Royal Family.
